There are some serious problems with this report (both the article and the video).
 
 It's self-contradictory, for one thing. It is made clear that the perpetrator and victim had not spoken to one another, so how is it possible for the attacker to have known the victim was gay to begin with?
 
 It is possible someone could have said 'that guy is gay' or something to that effect, but the article doesn't say, and therefore the second problem here is that there is just too little information here to make a judgment. At this point the facts are that a guy hit another guy with a pool cue stick, and the guy that got hit happens to be gay. That's about there is to go on at this point.
 
 This is a great example of the problem I (and many others) have with the concept of hate crime laws. They are subjective in that they attempt to make a crime out of prejudice, which is not an objective and provable concept. Law should be based on objectivism, not criminalizing something subjective. That people in this article are jumping to conclusions based on circumstantial evidence is exactly the sort of thing that is frightening about hate crime legislation.
